V. Kohli.scouting_report: Struggles against left-arm pace initially. Susceptible to deliveries outside off stump moving away.

S. Smith.scouting_report: Susceptible to leg-spin on turning tracks. Can be tied down by accurate short-pitched bowling.

J. Root.scouting_report: Strong against spin. Vulnerable to high pace early in the innings.

K. Williamson.scouting_report: Excellent technique. Sometimes struggles with playing away from the body against swing.

B. Azam.scouting_report: Classy driver. Can get bogged down by accurate spin bowling in middle overs.

R. Sharma.scouting_report: Destructive opener. Vulnerable to left-arm swing early on. NOTE: Rohit Sharma has retired from T20Is — not in T20 WC 2026.

SK. Yadav.scouting_report: India T20 WC 2026 captain. 360-degree batter. Susceptible to disciplined short-pitched pace targeting his body early in innings.
strengths: Ramp and scoop over fine leg

J. Bumrah.scouting_report: India's premier pace bowler. World-class yorker specialist. Difficult to score off in death overs. Tail-end batting liability.
weaknesses: Left-handers attacking his natural angle early in spell

Arshdeep Singh.scouting_report: India left-arm seamer. Outstanding with new ball and in death overs. Right-handers can target his angle over the off side.

Tilak Varma.scouting_report: Emerging left-handed middle-order batter for India. Can struggle against high-quality off-spin on turning tracks.
weaknesses: High pace short ball early in innings

Hardik Pandya.scouting_report: India all-rounder. Power hitter and seam bowling asset. Susceptible to quality leg-spin when trying to accelerate.
weaknesses: Outswing when batting early in innings

Varun Chakaravarthy.scouting_report: India mystery spinner with multiple variations. Can be attacked by confident sweepers early in his spell.

SK. Raza.scouting_report: Zimbabwe captain and key all-rounder. Experienced off-spinner and middle-order batter. Can be tied down by left-arm pace early.

B. Muzarabani.scouting_report: Zimbabwe's spearhead. Tall, high-action right-arm pace. Gets steep bounce. Can be driven when length is too full.
weaknesses: Left-handers cutting from outside off stump

B. Bennett.scouting_report: Zimbabwe's aggressive top-order batter. Positive intent. Can be dismissed playing across the line against quality inswing.
strengths: Aggressive intent at the top of the order

S. Hope.scouting_report: West Indies captain and anchor batter. Dependable but can struggle to accelerate against accurate off-spin in middle overs.

S. Rutherford.scouting_report: West Indies explosive middle-order batter. Unstoppable when set. Vulnerable to googly bowling early in innings.

R. Powell.scouting_report: West Indies power-hitter. Susceptible to accurate yorkers and good-length balls outside off stump.

R. Shepherd.scouting_report: West Indies pace-bowling all-rounder. Effective with new ball. Can be swept on spin-friendly conditions.
weaknesses: Sweep shots on slow surfaces when bowling

A. Markram.scouting_report: South Africa captain. Technically correct batter. Susceptible to left-arm spin in subcontinent conditions.

K. Rabada.scouting_report: South Africa pace spearhead. Generates genuine pace and bounce. Can be taken on by left-handers in powerplay.
weaknesses: Left-handers attacking his angle in powerplay

Q. de Kock.scouting_report: Destructive South Africa opener. Prone to nicking off against outswing early on.

D. Miller.scouting_report: Prolific South Africa finisher. Can be contained by accurate yorkers at the death.

J. Buttler.scouting_report: England wicket-keeper batter. Destructive when set. Can be tied down by accurate leg-spin early in innings.

P. Salt.scouting_report: England aggressive opener. Prone to nicking off against outswing deliveries.

L. Livingstone.scouting_report: England power hitter. Can be foxed by wrist-spin bowling angling into his body.

M. Santner.scouting_report: New Zealand captain and slow left-arm spinner. Economical. Can be attacked by aggressive left-handers hitting with the turn.

F. Allen.scouting_report: New Zealand explosive opener. Aggressive starter. Vulnerable to well-directed short balls from high pace.

D. Conway.scouting_report: New Zealand reliable left-handed opener. Strong technique. Susceptible to quality wrist spin on turning pitches.
weaknesses: Quality wrist spin on turning tracks
strengths: Flick and sweep off left arm

Shaheen Afridi.scouting_report: Pakistan lethal left-arm pace bowler. Dangerous with new ball. Can be driven through covers when length is too full.
weaknesses: Right-handers moving across stumps to negate swing

Fakhar Zaman.scouting_report: Pakistan left-handed aggressive opener. Susceptible to outswing nipping away from him.
weaknesses: Quality off-spin from around the wicket

Shadab Khan.scouting_report: Pakistan leg-spin all-rounder. Effective match-winner. Vulnerable to right-handers dancing down the track and hitting inside-out.
weaknesses: Flat pitches reducing turn and bounce

W. Hasaranga.scouting_report: Sri Lanka premier leg-spin all-rounder. World-class wrist spinner. Can be attacked by confident sweepers on flat tracks.
weaknesses: Flat tracks that limit bounce and spin

P. Nissanka.scouting_report: Sri Lanka attacking opener. Susceptible to pace targeting the body early in innings.
weaknesses: High pace targeting body line early
strengths: Drives through covers and extra cover

Kusal Mendis.scouting_report: Sri Lanka wicket-keeper batter. Capable of explosive innings. Can be dismissed by quality leg-spin early in his innings.
weaknesses: Yorkers at the death under pressure
strengths: Powerful hitting through the leg side

India.scouting_report: T20 WC 2026 defending champions. Led by Suryakumar Yadav (Rohit/Kohli retired from T20Is). World-class bowling attack. Playing at home gives massive advantage.
weaknesses: Top-order transition without Rohit and Kohli

Zimbabwe.scouting_report: Surprise Super 8 qualifiers after stunning win over Australia. Strong seam attack. Cohesive unit that punches above their weight.
weaknesses: Batting depth against world-class spin on flat Indian tracks
Limited big-match experience at this level

West Indies.scouting_report: Two-time T20 World Cup champions. Explosive batting lineup with powerful all-rounders. Dangerous on any surface.
weaknesses: Middle-overs spin bowling economy on turning tracks
Chasing large totals against quality leg-spin

South Africa.scouting_report: 2024 T20 WC runners-up. Balanced team with quality pace attack and dangerous batting line-up.
weaknesses: Historically poor knockout performance under pressure
Spin bowling depth on subcontinent turning tracks

England.scouting_report: Ultra-aggressive T20 side. Two-time T20 World Cup champions. Deep batting lineup with dangerous all-rounders.
strengths: Batting depth with variety (Buttler, Salt, Livingstone)
weaknesses: Consistency — can collapse from strong positions
Spin bowling quality on turning subcontinent tracks

New Zealand.scouting_report: Disciplined and cohesive side led by Santner. Good balance of pace and spin. Consistent performers in ICC tournaments.
strengths: Tight left-arm spin (Santner) and wrist spin (Sodhi)
Team cohesion and smart cricketing decisions
weaknesses: Batting depth against high-quality express pace

Pakistan.scouting_report: Talented but unpredictable. World-class pace attack when fit. Babar Azam key in middle order with Fakhar Zaman opening.
strengths: Left-arm pace threat (Shaheen Afridi, Naseem Shah)
weaknesses: Inconsistent batting top order under pressure
Fielding lapses and DRS decisions in crucial moments

Sri Lanka.scouting_report: Co-hosts and surprise package. Knocked out Australia in group stage. Strong spin attack, home conditions advantage.
strengths: Home/co-host conditions advantage in Sri Lanka
weaknesses: Batting fragility against high-quality pace under pressure

Wankhede Stadium.characteristics: Red soil, good bounce, high scoring. Dew factor is significant in evenings.
Wankhede Stadium.win_bias: Chasing team wins 60% of T20s due to dew and small boundaries.
Wankhede Stadium.pace_vs_spin: Pacers get initial swing; Spinners struggle due to short boundaries.

Melbourne Cricket Ground.characteristics: Huge boundaries, drop-in pitch. Balanced contest between bat and ball.
Melbourne Cricket Ground.win_bias: Teams batting first have a slight advantage in big finals.
Melbourne Cricket Ground.pace_vs_spin: Pacers enjoy the bounce; Spinners effective due to large boundaries.

Lord's.characteristics: Famous slope. Seam movement early on.
Lord's.win_bias: Balanced. Overhead conditions dictate the game.
Lord's.pace_vs_spin: Seam bowlers dominate. Spinners play a holding role.

Eden Gardens.characteristics: Black soil. Traditionally a spinner's paradise but recently aids pacers too.
Eden Gardens.win_bias: Chasing is preferred due to dew in winter.
Eden Gardens.pace_vs_spin: Spinners get grip and turn. Pacers get carry in evening.
